Sullivan | Doughty knew WKU could do it

Western Kentucky stuns undefeated Marshall with eye-popping offense

Sullivan | Doughty knew WKU could do it

Tim Sullivan, tsullivan@courier-journal.com 8:54 a.m. EST November 29, 2014

Western Kentuckys Brandon Doughty celebrates after throwing one of his eight touchdown passes against Marshall.(Photo: Getty Images)

21 CONNECT 9 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Brandon Doughty's admitted that his arm was tired, but the rest of him was rested. Western Kentucky's prolific quarterback threw 50 passes eight of them for touchdowns in Friday's 67-66 overtime upset of No. 19 Marshall, and he emerged from the experience as if he'd spent the day in a diner.

"I was sitting back there drinking shakes and eating cheeseburgers," Doughty said, crediting his blocking for his eye-bulging statistics. "We knew it was a good opportunity for us."

On the road as 23-point underdogs, facing an undefeated opponent that had won 13 straight home games, WKU arrived in Huntington, W.Va. armed with the idea that it would attack and accept the consequences.

    Though the odds were daunting, the Hilltoppers were undaunted.

    "We were going into the game being aggressive," Doughty said in a telephone interview before boarding the team bus. "We had nothing to lose."

    Western was already bowl-eligible. Doughty was already the nation's leader in touchdowns tossed. And though Marshall's 11-0 record was in large part a product to Conference USA's best defense, the Hilltoppers were able to find enough favorable matchups to amass 738 yards of total offense.

    COURIER-JOURNAL

    WKU hands Marshall first loss, 67-66 in overtime

    Doughty completed 34 passes to nine different receivers. Jared Dangerfield and Louisville's Taywan Taylor (Pleasure Ridge Park) both exceeded 100 yards in receiving for WKU and Tyler Higbee had 99 yards and three touchdowns. Senior Willie McNeal caught the two-point conversion that ended a game that included 74 first downs, 1,446 yards of total offense and a Football Bowl Subdivision record 15 touchdown passes.

    The victory improved Western's record to 7-5. The loss likely costs Marshall a chance at a New Year's Day bowl game.

    "It's a shock," Marshall tight end Eric Frohnapfel told the Associated Press afterward. "That was sort of the look on everyone's face. It's frustrating and people are angry."

    For Doughty, the senior from Davie, Fla., the post-game emotion was closer to euphoria. Pending those games yet to be played, Doughty leads the nation in touchdowns passes (44) and passing yards (4,344) and ranks second in completions (344). Both Doughty and Marshall's Rakeem Cato (29-46 for 417 yards and seven touchdowns) bettered Conference USA's previous record for touchdown passes in a game. But Cato also threw four interceptions, three of them by WKU sophomore Branden Leston, and all four preceded Hilltopper touchdowns.

    Doughty threw six touchdown passes in the first half alone, leading the Hilltoppers to a 49-42 halftime lead that seemed like something better suited to a video game.

    "They made a couple of comments before the game that shook me the wrong way. . ." Doughty said of the Thundering Herd. "I was really kind of locked-in in the first half, seeing things pretty clear."

    WKU failed to score in the third period, driving the ball from its own 1-yard line to the Marshall 8 before a sack and a missed field goal afforded the home team an opening for a game-tying touchdown drive. Western regained control with a field goal and Doughty's seventh touchdown pass, but Marshall forced overtime with a field goal and another tying touchdown in the last six minutes of regulation.

    After Marshall scored a touchdown on the first possession of overtime, taking its only lead of the game, WKU coach Jeff Brohm resolved to bring the game to a swift conclusion. He decided to go for the win following Doughty's eighth touchdown pass -- kicker Garrett Schwettman had injured an ankle in the third quarter and he watched as his quarterback rolled to his right and found McNeal open in the front corner of the end zone.

    "I don't think it's hit me yet, beating a team like that," Doughty said. "Maybe after a couple of days go by."

    Tim Sullivan can be reached at (502) 582-4650, by email at tsullivan@courier-journal.com, and on Twitter @TimSullivan714.
